replies.comment info: While it’s true that the number of nuclear warheads has decreased significantly since the Cold War, with both the US and Russia working to reduce their arsenals through treaties like START that involve inspections and verification, the question of whether this makes us safer remains complex. Russia currently has the most warheads, and although many have been retired, dismantling them doesn’t mean the materials disappear, and waste disposal remains a major challenge. Not all warheads are equal—some, like hydrogen bombs, are vastly more powerful than older designs—adding to the danger. Eliminating nuclear weapons entirely is a difficult goal due to technical, political, and security concerns, but reducing and preventing proliferation is crucial. The existence of these weapons still poses a significant threat, and their presence underscores that true safety depends not just on decreasing numbers but on ongoing international cooperation and strict disarmament efforts.
